issue.title: Exception chains can be navigated when dropped into Pdb in Python 3.13+

labels.name: bot:chronographer:provided
labels.description: (automation) changelog entry is part of PR

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.title: Document `pdb.post_mortem()` accepts exceptions on Python 3.13+
issue.body:
# Documentation

Some change in Python 3.13 (maybe 5f3433f210d25d366fcebfb40adf444c8f46cd59 or related) allows `pdb.post_mortem()` to accept an exception object, as well as a traceback object. This could be useful to use for chained exception access, for example in Djangoâ€™s test runner where [a traceback is currently passed](https://github.com/django/django/blob/8d9901c961bf9d5cfa6bddddbbcebfbf487a5125/django/test/runner.py#L124-L129), but the exception with chained causes is available.

Tested with:

```python
import pdb

try:
    try:
        1 / 0
    except Exception:
        2 / 0
except Exception as exc:
    pdb.post_mortem(exc)
```

and ran with:

```
$ uv run -p 3.13 python example.py
> /.../example.py(7)<module>()
-> 2 / 0
(Pdb) exceptions
    0 ZeroDivisionError('division by zero')
>   1 ZeroDivisionError('division by zero')
(Pdb) exceptions 0
> /.../example.py(5)<module>()
-> 1 / 0
(Pdb)
```


<!-- gh-linked-prs -->
### Linked PRs
* gh-128410
* gh-128767
<!-- /gh-linked-prs -->

issue.title: Better Scenario error message surfacing

repository.name: operator
repository.description: Pure Python framework for writing Juju charms

issue.body:
Wrapping operator-raised errors with UncaughtCharmError can be misleading. Reconsider that choice and possibly let the charm errors bubble up.

Given this code:

```py
class SomeCharm(ops.CharmBase):
    ...
    def _on_relation(self, event):
        assert event.something == some_sanity_check
```

I'd expect to run `pytest --pdb` and get dropped into this failing assertion line.

Instead, I'm getting:

```
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> entering PDB >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>

>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> PDB post_mortem >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
> /code/hexanator/.tox/unit/lib/python3.12/site-packages/scenario/runtime.py(469)exec()
-> raise UncaughtCharmError(
(Pdb)
```

And I can't get to the original line that triggered the exception.

Here's a cleaned up back trace for reference:

```
_pytest/python.py(162)pytest_pyfunc_call()
-> result = testfunction(**testargs)

tests/unit/test_scenario.py(56)test_rate_limit()
-> ctx.run(ctx.on.relation_created(relation), initial_state)

scenario/context.py(613)run()
-> with self._run_event(event=event, state=state) as ops:

contextlib.py(158)__exit__()
-> self.gen.throw(value)

scenario/context.py(598)_run_event()
-> with self._run(event=event, state=state) as ops:

contextlib.py(158)__exit__()
-> self.gen.throw(value)

scenario/context.py(660)_run()
-> with runtime.exec(

contextlib.py(158)__exit__()
-> self.gen.throw(value)

scenario/runtime.py(469)exec()
-> raise UncaughtCharmError(
```

Moved from https://github.com/canonical/ops-scenario/issues/76 and https://github.com/canonical/ops-scenario/issues/154

issue.title: Support changes made in pytest 8.4.0+ for Python 3.13+

repository.name: pdbp
repository.description: pdbp (Pdb+): A drop-in replacement for pdb and pdbpp. To replace "pdb", add "import pdbp" to an "__init__.py" file.

issue.body:
## Support changes made in pytest 8.4.0+ for Python 3.13+

`pytest` `8.4.0`, (which shipped on June 2, 2025) included this major change: https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/12707 - (https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/commit/3cc88d980166e0741f69c00bd7acbb0a245dcaec), which takes advantage of a new feature in Python 3.13 where the `pdb` debugger `interaction` method now accepts both a traceback and an exception (not just the traceback anymore). This has led to an issue with `pdbp`, which hasn't yet made the necessary updates, causing exceptions like the below to occur when running `pytest --pdb` (and there's an exception):

```python
AttributeError: 'NoSuchElementException' object has no attribute 'tb_frame'
```

Traceback:

```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
...
  File "/Users/michael/.virtualenvs/python_3_13/lib/python3.13/site-packages/_pytest/debugging.py", line 405, in post_mortem
    p.interaction(None, tb_or_exc)
    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/Users/michael/github/pdbp/src/pdbp.py", line 297, in interaction
    ret = self.setup(frame, traceback)
  File "/Users/michael/.virtualenvs/python_3_13/lib/python3.13/site-packages/_pytest/debugging.py", line 221, in setup
    ret = super().setup(f, tb)
  File "/Users/michael/github/pdbp/src/pdbp.py", line 349, in setup
    ret = super().setup(frame, tb)
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.13/lib/python3.13/pdb.py", line 391, in setup
    self.stack, self.curindex = self.get_stack(f, tb)
                                ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^^
  File "/Users/michael/.virtualenvs/python_3_13/lib/python3.13/site-packages/_pytest/debugging.py", line 230, in get_stack
    stack, i = super().get_stack(f, t)
               ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^
  File "/Users/michael/github/pdbp/src/pdbp.py", line 377, in get_stack
    fullstack, idx = super().get_stack(f, t)
                     ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~^^^^^^
  File "/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/3.13/lib/python3.13/bdb.py", line 601, in get_stack
    if t and t.tb_frame is f:
             ^^^^^^^^^^
AttributeError: 'AttributeError' object has no attribute 'tb_frame'
```
